metadata.title: Assessment of enhanced nitrite removal and monitoring using ligand modified stable conjugate materials

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/cej
Assessment of enhanced nitrite removal and monitoring using ligand modified stable conjugate materials
Md. Rabiul Awuala,b,c,⁎, Abdullah M. Asirib, Mohammed M. Rahmanb, Nabeel H. Alharthic
a Department of Chemical Engineering, Curtin University, GPO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6845, Australia b Center of Excellence for Advanced Materials Research, Faculty of Science, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah 21589, Saudi Arabia cMechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Saud University, Riyadh 11421, Saudi Arabia
H I G H L I G H T S
• Conjugate material was fabricated for enhanced capturing of nitrite (NO2−) ions. • The material is able to effectively NO2− capturing in the presence of foreign ions. • The solution pH 5.50 was effective for selective monitoring and removal operations. • The conjugate materials were exhibited the high removal capacity of 119.22 mg/g.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Toxic nitrite (NO2−) Conjugate materials Capturing High removal efficiency Multi-cycle reuses
A B S T R A C T
In this study, stable conjugate material was fabricated by functional organic ligand embedded onto the porous silica for efficient detection and adsorption of toxic nitrite (NO2−) ions from contaminated water. The detection method was obviously detected the NO2− ions even in the ultra-trace amount with significant color formation. Several experimental frameworks, including pH effect, reaction time, low limit detection, competing ions effect, maximum removal capacity and reuses were investigated systematically both in the detection and removal operations. The low limit of detection was 0.16 µg/L, which was compiled the high-sensitivity detection of the NO2− ions. The solution pH was displayed a key factor, and it was optimized carefully. The optimum pH was 5.50 both in the detection and adsorption mode in this study. The contact time showed that the kinetics performance was slow compared with previous several nanomaterials. This was postulated that the NO2− ions removed as monovalent and consisted in wastewater as anions. The adsorption trend was highly competent according to Langmuir isotherms, and the highest removal capacity was 119.22 mg/g by the conjugate materials for NO2− ions. Several cations and anions were tested as the competing ions, however, these were not affected the NO2− ion in both operations as the strong affinity of the conjugate materials functionality was expected to the NO2− ions at suitable conditions. The data also emphasized that the conjugate material has potentiality under the suitable experimental protocol for the NO2− ions capturing from the polluted waters. Thus the conjugate materials will attract the scientific community in as promising material in nanotechnology for NO2− ions capturing.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2019.01.125 Received 22 November 2018; Received in revised form 28 December 2018; Accepted 19 January 2019
⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical Engineering, Curtin University, GPO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6845, Australia. E-mail addresses: rabiul.awual@curtin.edu.au, awual75@yahoo.com (Md. R. Awual).
Chemical Engineering Journal 363 (2019) 64–72
Available online 22 January 2019 1385-8947/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The adverse effect of nitrogen containing anions like nitrite (NO2−) into groundwater is well-known for human beings. Several NO2− salts are used in manufacturing process of industrial products. The industrial waste containing NO2− is throwing to the environment without purification in many countries. Then the NO2− intake in excess amount can cause the transformation of normal hemoglobin to methemoglobin and subsequently deficiency of hemoglobin’s ability to carry oxygen [1]. Moreover, NO2− has ability to connect with amines to form carcinogenic nitrosamines [2,3]. Also the NO2− has dangerously affected to the young infants by severe injury even death by asphyxia [4]. The World Health Organization besides the US Environmental Protection Agency recommended the limits of NO2− in drinking water under 3mg/L and 1mg/L, respectively [5,6]. So, it is important to prepare highly efficient and reliable materials for suitable NO2− ions detection and adsorption from contaminated water samples.
The anion selectivity is completely different than the cation capturing based on the Hofmeister ion selectivity [7]. There are several hydrophobic materials those are have high affection to the lowly hydrated anions to highly hydrated even the charge number of anions are equal [8,9]. Then the complexation mechanism can solve the ion selectivity due to the stand point of potential use in real operation. Several analytical methods for the toxic ions both of cations and anions detection has been indicated according to their specific bonding and separation methodologies such as spectrophotometry, ion chromatography, kinetic methods, electrometric, electrochemical, luminescence, and fluorimetry [10–19]. However, the Griess–Ilosvay reaction has good sensitivity and selectivity for NO2− ions [20]. Usually, these methods are attractive in the developing countries due to the cost, onsite and professional trained analyst factors [21]. Therefore, reliable materials are always welcome in the scientific community for the detection of toxic monovalent NO2− ions without using highly sophisticated machines and apparatus. In the last few years, we have fabricated several ligand anchoring nanomaterials for target cations and anions detection and removal from the point of view of sensitivity and selectivity [22]. These materials are low cost, reliable for on-site use, and technologically suitable because of the case cavity and morphological stability for capturing of the cations and anions. From this connection, we have prepared 1,1′-bi-2-naphthol (BINOL) based stable conjugate materials for efficient monitoring and adsorption of NO2− ions where the significant color was formed after contacting the NO2− ions with conjugate materials at a suitable experimental protocol. It is also indicated that The porous silica of the carrier nanomaterials exhibited abundant hydroxyl group and BINOL was embedded by the hydrogen bonding, Van der Waals forces and reversible covalent bonds [17,23].
Over the last decades, several techniques such as liquid-liquid extraction, co-precipitation, flocculation, membrane filtration, ion-exchange complexation, and biological materials have been reported for toxic cations and anions removal from wastewater [24–30]. The solvent extraction is usually known as liquid-liquid separation as a common mode but this is creating sludge and required many chemicals, therefore; this is highly expensive method compared with the other methods [31–33]. Moreover, many of the above techniques have some limitations from the stand point of selectivity, low level concentration removal, reuses cycles and easy-to-use without need of the extreme costly apparatus [32]. Several adsorbent materials such as activated carbon, activated alumina, porous zeolite and multiwall carbon nanotubes for metal ions removal from wastewater samples [34,35]. These materials confronted with some difficulties, including low removal capacity, less selective and unable to reuses [31,33]. The nanomaterials based nanotechnology is the substitute choice because of the materials functionality to settle down all disputes. The nanomaterials are working as potential adsorbent because these are exhibited high removal capacity, extreme efficiency even in low concentration level, able to reuse in several series without major loss in its working functionality and low
cost [36,37]. Then the nanomaterials have gained scientific community attentions as the nanoparticles have shown many unsaturated atoms on their outer and inner surface to take-up the complexation and coordination bonding to the metal ions for serving as highly sensitivity and selectivity of ultra-trace concentration level [22,23]. We have been reported several functionalized nanomaterials based on the organic ligands anchoring for several ions removal and recovery [38–43]. In this association, the ordered silica was synthesized and functionalized ligand of BINOL was anchored successfully. The ligand has ability to make complexation with the NO2− ions at the optimum condition both in the detection and removal operations. In addition, the ligand exhibited the specific selectivity and rapid sensitivity for NO2− ions in the presence of diverse competing ions. Then the organic ligand of BINOL was selected in this work. This work was aimed to present the inspection of visual monitoring and adsorption of toxic NO2− ions.
In this work, we have developed ligand based conjugate materials for the low-cost, easy and quick technique for toxic NO2− ions detection and removal optically from the contaminated wastewater. The experimental parameters for influencing the NO2− ions in terms of detection and removal operation such as solution pH, reaction time, and effect of primary concentration, competing ions and reuses was optimized and the performance was systematically evaluated. The new conjugate material was revealed extreme affinity to the ultra-trace amount of NO2− ions. The high sensitivity and selectivity of towards NO2− ions was displayed, which was visualized by the naked-eye with significant color formation and this was implied the charge-transfer mechanism upon complexation between conjugate materials surface and the NO2− ions.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: All reagents were used as received for the experimental works in this study. The tetramethylorthosilicate (TMOS), sodium nitrite and F108 (EO141PO44EO141) were bought from Sigma-Aldrich chemicals. The 1,1′-bi-2-naphthol (BINOL) was from Merck. All solutions were in AAS grade. For pH adjustments, the buffer solution MOPS, CHES, CAPS, KCl, HCl, NaOH were used as the experimental protocol.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of mesoporous silica
sections.text: The carrier materials inorganic mesoporous silica nanomaterials were prepared by using direct templating method where the typical conditions of the each composition ratio of F108:TMOS:HCl/H2O was 1.3:2:1 respectively. The homogeneous solution of sol-gel was observed by mixing F108/TMOS in a 200mL beaker by shaking at 60 °C until homogeneous. The exothermic hydrolysis and condensation of TMOS happened after addition of aqueous solution HCl (at pH=1.3) to this homogeneous solution. The methanol produced from the TMOS hydrolysis was removed by a rotary evaporator at 45 °C. Then the materials were dried at 45 °C for 24 h to complete the drying process. The organic moieties were removed by calcination at 520 °C for 6 h under the normal atmosphere. After calcinations, the material was grounded properly and ready to use as effective carrier materials for fabrication stable conjugate materials after successful inclusion of organic BINOL.

sections.heading: 2.3. Fabrication of solid conjugate material
sections.text:
The preparation of mesoporous material is displayed in Scheme 1. The silica material was synthesized by the direct approach where 1.0 g of the grinded porous silica was mixed 60mg of BINOL into 50mL ethanol solution and agitated for 6 h. After complete separation, the mesoporous material was rinsed with water several times to check leaching of the organic compound. The highest anchoring was optimized to get the maximum adsorption capacity by the mesoporous
materials. The mesoporous material was dried at 55 °C for 12 h. The ligand saturation amount was determined (1.40 mmol/g) according to the below equation:
= − −Q C C V m( ) /0 (1)
where Q is the embedded ligand amount (mmol/g), V is the solution volume (L), m is the amount of silica (g), C0 and C are the initial and final concentration of the 1,1′-bi-2-naphthol, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.4. The NO2− ions detection procedure
sections.text: The color formation in the monitoring of NO2− ions using conjugate materials was performed in the broad pH ranges. In each fraction, the NO2− concentration and conjugate materials amount (10mg) were the same and the solution pH was varied from 2.0 to 11.0 ranges where the solution volume was 10mL. Then the solution mixture was shaken by mechanical shaker for 10min. After that the solid mesoporous material was isolated by suction filtration operation. The color assessment was carried out by optical vision using UV–vis absorption operations.

sections.heading: 2.5. Instruments and analysis
sections.text:
The specific surface area was determined using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (BET, Micromeritics, Tristar II) and the porosity was also measured with the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH). To define the NO2− ions color intensity, UV–Vis/ spectrophotometer (JASCO/ V-670) was utilized in the solid state mode. The SEM analysis was carried out on Hitachi S-4300 operated at 16 keV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was obtained by using a JEOL (JEM-2010) at standard procedure. The NO2− ions concentrations were determined using ICPAES at standard calibration mode (Perkin Elmer-8300).
All experiments were carried out at least duplicated to satisfy the consistency and reproducibility of the extracted results.

sections.heading: 3.1. The properties mesoporous silica
sections.text:
The porous silica materials, which are used to be a carrier for the ligand, should have favored characteristics regarding mesoporous
structure, surface area and porosity and pores volumes. These characteristics enable mesoporous silica to enhance the properties of the carried organic ligand such as selectivity and sensitivity. Therefore, we have investigated the effect of the carried ligand on the characteristics of mesoporous itself by comparing these characteristics of silica before and after modification of the surface by the organic ligand of BINOL.
From the N2 adsorption–desorption data, the mesoporous silica was exhibited the type IV, with highly ordered structure and the broad hysteresis loop at p/po= 0.75–1.0 as shown in Fig. 1(A). The data compiled with the bimodal mesostructure as depicted in Fig. 1(B). The pore of 9.7 nm was clarified that the mesoporous silica template with bulk phage [38,40,42,43]. The mesoporosity was also evident even after ligand anchoring onto the carrier silica materials. However, the extended pore on the conjugate material surface was shrinkage the mesostructure subsequently.
The N2 isotherms data are depicted in Fig. 1(A) and the total surface area of the carrier mesoporous silica was higher than the ligand
Scheme 1. Fabrication of 1,1′-bi-2-naphthol based conjugate materials and the NO2− ions capturing with significant color formation.
anchoring stable conjugate materials as expected. The total surface area of the silica materials and the ligand immobilized conjugate materials was 603 and 416m2/g, respectively. Similarly, the pore volume was decreased and the values are 0.75 and 0.47 cm3/g for the carrier inorganic silica and the ligand embedded conjugate materials, respectively. The reduction of surface and pore volume region in the wake of stacking due to the anchoring of BINOL was embedded and all around scattered on the carrier silica surfaces. Also, the perceptions uncover because the conjugate material holds their meso-structure, which was the vital angle to take into account BINOL accessibility by inorganic silica. The pore distribution of porous silica is also shown in Fig. 1 (inset). This also noted that the particle shapes were observed from the range of 100–200 nm and it was affirmed by the TEM images as clarified in Fig. 2(A–D). The SEM of the silica sample and ligand embedded conjugate material are depicted in Fig. 2(E, F). According to the SEM images, particles are revealed those are spherical morphologies.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Recognition process in terms of pH for NO2− ions using conjugate materials
sections.text: The potentiality and extreme performance of the ligand fabricated conjugate materials are affected by the solution pH, reaction time, complexation mechanism, the amount of the fabricated materials and suitable condition [44,45]. In the detection system, the materials homogeneity also enhanced the color formation as well as signal intensity in terms of significant color visualization by naked-eye. The signal intensity upon addition NO2− ions to the conjugate materials was carried based on the solution acidity. The results are shown in Fig. 3. The optical color formation and high absorbance were observed at pH 5.50. This is because the strong complexation was expected in this pH region. The NO2− ions amount, solution volume other parameters were the same in each pH fraction. The adsorption pH was also the same as that of the detection pH by the conjugate materials. Therefore, pH 5.50 was selected as the optimum condition to define the other experimental parameters in this study. The removal pH was also the same as that of the detection mode. Then the removal pH effect was not stated in the adsorption study.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Visualization of NO2− ions by conjugate material
sections.text:
The developed conjugate material was shown excellent enhancement for efficient recognition of the NO2−. The current conjugate
material was functioned of the porous silica advanced features after immobilization of the organic ligand. The prepared conjugate materials were high sensitive even in the addition of ultra-trace amount of NO2− ions. With increasing the NO2− ions concentration, the color was optimized and similarly the absorbance signal intensity was increased as concluded in Fig. 4. The data defined that the chemical conjugate material has offered easy recognition both in quantification and visual color formation for the NO2− ions without using highly sophisticated apparatus. However, the colorimetric studies utilizing signal measurement by UV–vis implemented quantitative detection and recognition range (DR) in the NO2− ions in the detection approach.
3.2.3. Detection and quantification The calibration data were plotted in the low-level concentration as
defined in the preceding Fig. 4 and data were defined as the linear correlation as shown in Fig. 5. The linear curves clarified that the NO2− can be monitored in the broad range of concentration with extreme sensitivity. The limit detection (LD) and quantitation (LQ) were determined from the following equation [32,42,43].
=L or L kSD Q b m/ (2)
where Sb and m are belonged to the standard deviation and the slope, k value was assumed to be 3 and 10 towards the determination of LD and LQ, respectively. The low detection limit (LD) was measured, and the value was 0.16 µg/L, which was lower than any conventional methods. At the same time, the quantification limit was determined, and the value was also low as 0.59 µg/L. The data are comparable with different significant materials related to this parameter [46–48].

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Ion-selective detection
sections.text:
The ions selectivity is the vital inspection to understand the largescale implementation of the fabricated materials. The NO2− ion is monovalent and usually the higher valence elements are competed according to the ion-exchange mechanism theory [7,8]. From this point of view, several ions, including cations and anions were investigated by the conjugate materials where the NO2− ion was fixed at 0.5mg/L. In addition, the data were presented in Table 1. The results showed that these diverse ions were not affected the NO2− ions detection by the conjugate materials. Therefore, the proposed conjugate material is the highly potential candidate for large-scale application from its high
affinity to the NO2− ions.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Detection of NO2− in tap, rain and wastewater
sections.text: The appropriateness of the proposed approach for NO2− ion detection in tap and rain water samples. The data revealed that the analyses and the method were accurate based on the recoveries and standard deviation percentage as the data are summarized in Table 2.

sections.heading: 3.3. Stability of the conjugate materials
sections.text: The long-time structural stability is an important criterion for largescale uses as the scientists are expecting such parameters as the main advantages. Then the proposed conjugate materials were kept six months in the dark place as we have performed previously to evaluate the materials stability measurement [28]. This is noted that the materials color can be changed due to the light affected and then the materials were kept in dark place. The materials color and morphology were carried out again, and no remarkable changes were observed. Therefore, the conjugate materials are highly potential to keep remaining functionality even after several months for NO2− ions detection from contaminated wastewaters.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Effect of contact time
sections.text:
The adsorption kinetic is always important due to the practical use
in large-scale to understand the complexation mechanism. Then an equilibrium contact time was defined based on the conjugate materials surface and NO2− ions adsorption. A series of batch fractions was carried out where the initial concentration, solution volume, solution pH, conjugate materials amounts were fixed, and the time were variables. The data were summarized in Fig. 6, where the adsorption was taken up as a function of reaction time. The adsorption was slow kinetics compared with the previously reported materials based on the ligand anchoring materials [7,9]. However, the 2 h was enough for complete adsorption from the solution as judged from Fig. 6. Therefore, little higher time was assumed for evaluating of the maximum removal amount by the conjugate materials.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Adsorption isotherms and capacity
sections.text:
The saturated adsorption is to comply with the nature of binding
towards the target ions, and the proposed materials surface at functionality. Then we have performed the equilibrium capacity of NO2− adsorption by the conjugate materials. The NO2− concentrations were varied from 1.0 to 50mg/L. In addition, the conjugate materials amount was fixed at 10mg, and the solution pH was 5.50. The results are shown in Fig. 7(A). The adsorption of NO2− was enhanced with enhancing the initial NO2− ions amount, and then it was shaped as the
plateau as judged from Fig. 7(A). Then the maximum amount adsorption of NO2− can be estimated by different adsorption isotherm models. The conjugate materials were exhibited highly porous even after ligand anchoring, then it was expected that the Langmuir adsorption model will be well fitted where the specific homogenous site of conjugate materials functionality was opened. The Langmuir isotherms model complies with the adsorbed ions occupied to the open functional sites, and no binding can be observed to the occupied surface sites [42,43,45]. In addition, the adsorption will take place in the monolayer with homogeneity. Therefore, maximum adsorption capacity was determined from the following Langmuir isotherm equation [49].
= +C q C q K q/ / 1/e e e m L m (3)
The qe and Ce are the adsorption amount (mg/g) and liquid state NO2− ions amount at equilibrium state (mg/L), respectively. The qm denoted the maximum adsorption amount of the proposed conjugate material (mg/g), and KL is the Langmuir constant (L/mg) belong to the active surface sites and counted through the adsorption energy. The KL and qm were assumed from the linear plot of Ce/qe versus Ce according to the values of intercept and slope as judged from Fig. 7(A) (inset). The coefficient value of 0.989 confirmed that monolayer was existed in the Langmuir model, which was occurred by the conjugate materials
towards the toxic NO2− ions. The maximum adsorption capacity was as high as 119.22mg/g and this was because of the high surface area of the conjugate materials as well as abundant active functional sites. The conjugate material displayed considerable adsorption efficiency comparing with other forms of materials in Table 3 [3,50–55], and the data confirmed that the fabricated conjugate material has high potentiality for toxic NO2− ions capturing from wastewater.

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Elution and reuses
sections.text:
The elution, regeneration and several cycle uses are an important
criterion as the cost-effective. The nanomaterials are exhibited in multicycle uses after elution/regeneration operation [25,40–43]. From this connection, the adsorbed NO2− ions were eluted with 0.10M NaOH. This is noted that the regeneration was taken at the same time during elution operation. After washing with water, the conjugate materials were used for the next capturing systems. After several cycles, the nanomaterials were kept high efficiency as judged from Fig. 7(B).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
This study was offered the spectrophotometric direction and adsorption of NO2− by the conjugate materials in colorimetric approach. The conjugate materials were fabricated by BINOL ligand anchoring onto the porous silica by the direct anchoring method. The conjugate materials could detect the NO2− ion by one-step process and detection limit was 0.16 µg/L. The fabricated conjugate materials were the firsttime facilities in efficient capturing of NO2− ion by optical color vision. The competing ions were not affected adversely in terms of detection and removal processes. The adsorption process was monolayer and appropriated to the Langmuir isotherms model. The determined maximum removal amount of NO2− ion by the conjugate materials was
119.22mg/L at pH 5.50. The elution operation was possible using an eluent of 0.10M NaOH solution and reuses was displayed in several cycles without significant deterioration of the primary performances. Then it was postulated that the detection removal process was efficient way for enabling capturing of NO2− ions from polluted waters. Thus we anticipated that this conjugate material could use as an effective material for ultra-trace NO2− ions capturing in practical environments.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The authors extend their appreciation to the International Scientific Partnership Program ISPP at King Saud University for funding this research work through ISPP# 87. The author also wishes to thanks to the anonymous reviewers and editor for their helpful suggestions and enlightening comments.
